user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of build_connection_chunked_response_footer:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
build_connection_chunked_response_footer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  char *buf;           /**< the buffer to write footers to */
  size_t buf_size;     /**< the size of the @a buf */
  size_t used_size;    /**< the used size of the @a buf */
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  mhd_assert (connection->rp.props.chunked);
  /* TODO: allow combining of the final footer with the last chunk,
   * modify the next assert. */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_CHUNKED_BODY_SENT == connection->state);
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->rp.response);

  buf_size = connection_maximize_write_buffer (c);
  /* '5' is the minimal size of chunked footer ("0\r\n\r\n") */
  if (buf_size < 5)
    return MHD_NO;
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->write_buffer);
  buf = c->write_buffer + c->write_buffer_append_offset;
  mhd_assert (NULL != buf);
  used_size = 0;
  buf[used_size++] = '0';
  buf[used_size++] = '\r';
  buf[used_size++] = '\n';

  for (pos = c->rp.response->first_header; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (MHD_FOOTER_KIND == pos->kind)
    {
      size_t new_used_size; /* resulting size with this header */
      /* '4' is colon, space, linefeeds */
      new_used_size = used_size + pos->header_size + pos->value_size + 4;
      if (new_used_size > buf_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      memcpy (buf + used_size, pos->header, pos->header_size);
      used_size += pos->header_size;
      buf[used_size++] = ':';
      buf[used_size++] = ' ';
      memcpy (buf + used_size, pos->value, pos->value_size);
      used_size += pos->value_size;
      buf[used_size++] = '\r';
      buf[used_size++] = '\n';
      mhd_assert (used_size == new_used_size);
    }
  }
  if (used_size + 2 > buf_size)
    return MHD_NO;
  buf[used_size++] = '\r';
  buf[used_size++] = '\n';

  c->write_buffer_append_offset += used_size;
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= c->write_buffer_size);

  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided function. The code uses only standard C constructs: a normal function declaration (static enum ...), pointer and const pointer declarations, standard types (size_t, char *), standard library call memcpy, NULL checks and standard for-loop iteration. The /**< ... */ comments are Doxygen-style comments (comments are not language extensions). There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm/asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ...; (expr); }), variable-length array extensions, nonstandard pragmas, or other vendor-specific keywords. The mhd_assert and other identifiers are macro/function calls but their expansions are not present here; nothing in this fragment explicitly uses a documented compiler extension. Therefore no code fragment in this function needs to be flagged for Rule 1.2.
